messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Strange that they re not covered.  My book on Japanese birds lists the following owls: Shiro-fukurou Washi-mimizuku Shima-fukurou Torafu-zuku Komimi-zuku
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
Strange that they're not covered. My book on Japanese birds lists the following owls:

Shiro-fukurou
Washi-mimizuku
Shima-fukurou
Torafu-zuku
Komimi-zuku
Fukurou
Minami-menfukurou
Konoha-zuku
Ou-konoha-zuku
Kinme-fukurou
Aoba-zuku

fwiw,
Jim



Jim et al-
I have done some digging too. I looked thru all of the gadai
jiten and there are no owls. I have seen "horned-owls" in kodogu.
Another name for owl is mimizuku, perhaps someone will find a
reference under that name...
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 7/21/2003 2:49:51 PM Central Daylight Time, ... Jim und all, I found a tsuba with owl motif  by Nobuie, it s illustrated in that exhibition
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 7/21/2003 2:49:51 PM Central Daylight Time,
jggilbert@... writes:

> In addition to the fierce hawks and occasional rooster, the first Jingo
> made at least one tsuba with an owl motif. I suspect that the intended meaning
> of the owl may have been along the same lines of courage and martial spirit.
>

Jim und all,
I found a tsuba with owl motif by Nobuie, it's illustrated in that
exhibition catalog ( page 63 ).
I can't translate the title of the catalog accurately.....it's something like
Nihonto kodogu research society ( museum opening commemorative )

Milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, I also did some google searching on the Japanese word for owl, fukurou.  I found some toys claiming the owl as a symbol of good luck, but I have a feeling
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
I also did some google searching on the Japanese word for owl, fukurou. I found some toys claiming the owl as a symbol of good luck, but I have a feeling that these modern associations have more to do with marketing than historical accuracy.

In books and web I mostly found the negative meanings already posted, but these didn't make much sense in relation to sword mountings. (Unless maybe as a memento mori type reminder that you might have to kill your own family members to get ahead. True in the 16th C, but maybe not a very popular idea in the Confucian-minded Edo period.)

In Katherine Ball's "Decorative Motives of Oriental Art" I found a brief mention of the owl being noted for the ability to kill birds its own size. In addition to the fierce hawks and occasional rooster, the first Jingo made at least one tsuba with an owl motif. I suspect that the intended meaning of the owl may have been along the same lines of courage and martial spirit.

I didn't find any exact homonyms for fukurou, but there are two kanji pronounced fukuro that mean "a return trip." No idea if that was intended, but returning home alive could certainly be an auspicious association.

Oddly I can't find fukurou listed in Tsuba Kodogu Gaidai Jiten.

Jim



Playing around on google.com the following was taken from a site selling owl toys and things. it sounds more "friendly" than the earlier meanings associated with the owl and would seem more like what the sword owner wanted by placing the owl on his sword's fittings. Sorry...didn't intent to beat this to death...

PAMPAS GRASS HORNED OWL: SUSUKI-MIMIZUKU
Dating back 250 years, the familiar grass horned owl is said to help ward off sickness. Though the owl is generally regarded in Japan as malicious or at best useless, this particular toy is widely recognized for its benevolence.

For what it's worth...

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 7/20/2003 8:18:22 AM Central Daylight Time, ... gang, Here s another information  on owls which i bet very few people can dig out from any
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 7/20/2003 8:18:22 AM Central Daylight Time,
warlord@... writes:

> Lovely work, and I
> was surprised to read the bad vibes about owls. What then does it signify
> on a
> kashira that faces toward everybody a samurai would pass as he
> walked/swaggered/strode/bounced/mooched/slunk along a street?? Hmmm.
>
> Regards,
>
> Barry Thomas
>

gang,
Here's another information on owls which i bet very few people can dig out
from any books.................
From what I understand the owls are used as " medicinal foods " to cure bed
wetting.
I kid you not.............. just ask any old folks in any Asian food markets
in the old countries ( by that I mean Singapore, Hong Kong, China,
Korea..........may be Japan by extrapolation since there's tremendous
cultural/culinary exchange ).

Milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?
messages.msgSnippet: Well, again for what it s worth, a mate of mine has a delightful pair of iron fuchigashira with an owl actually sticking up above the outline of the kashira.
messages.messageBody:
Well, again for what it's worth, a mate of mine has a delightful pair of iron
fuchigashira with an owl actually "sticking up" above the outline of the
kashira. I couls stick an image up somewhere if any one is interested - it
would take me a couple weeks due to pressing committment. Lovely work, and I
was surprised to read the bad vibes about owls. What then does it signify on a
kashira that faces toward everybody a samurai would pass as he
walked/swaggered/strode/bounced/mooched/slunk along a street?? Hmmm.

Regards,

Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann <swords@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, July 20, 2003 6:49 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?

toys and things. it sounds more "friendly" than the earlier meanings associated
with the owl and would seem more like what the sword owner wanted by placing the
owl on his sword's fittings. Sorry...didn't intent to beat this to death...

PAMPAS GRASS HORNED OWL: SUSUKI-MIMIZUKU
Dating back 250 years, the familiar grass horned owl is said to help ward off

For what it's worth...

Ron

PAMPAS GRASS HORNED OWL: SUSUKI-MIMIZUKU

----- Original Message -----
From: David Zincavage
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, July 19, 2003 12:52 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?


What references did you use, Ron?
----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, July 19, 2003 10:40 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?


Hi David -

After asking about this subject I did locate a couple references to the owl motif, both very dark and negative as you pointed out. One called the owl the "messenger of the devil!" Thinking about this, I wonder why the owl would had been used on kodogu, specifically menuki, unless of course it was to imply death from the sword, or something like that. (Seems the poor old owl is getting a bad rap! Neat bird!)

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: David Zincavage
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, July 19, 2003 12:03 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?


I have found it necessary recently to lay in some references on the subject to satisfy my own curiosity:

Hibi Sadao and Niwa Motoji, "Snow, Wave, Pine -- Traditional Patterns in Japanese Design," Kodansha, 2001.

Merrily Brand, "Symbols of Japan -- Thematic Motifs in Art and Design," Rizzoli, 2001.

I have a third out-of-print title on order.

Hibi & Niwa do not discuss the owl.

Baird (113-114) writes:

"OWL. The owl figured prominently in the artistic symbolism of the ancient Chinese, who seemed to have viewed the nocturnal bird as capable of making the realm of night and darkness safer. With the passage of time, the owl's apparent role as mediator of the world of darkness waned, however, and it came to be viewed with dread. Moreover, there arose the belief in China that owlets devoured their mothers, and the bird thereby became a symbol of filial betrayal. It was these later, negative associations that crossed from China to Japan. Because the owl (_fukuro_) is generally considered evil, and an omen of death, it only rarely appears on personal and household objects in Japan.

David
----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy
Sent: Friday, July 18, 2003 4:25 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?


Hi -

Looking at some menuki depicting (I think) a male and female owl sitting in a pine tree (branch). Realized I never really understood the meaning of the "owl" and thought somebody might jump in here and explain it for all to learn from.

Thanks!

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, I should had bought a copy of that index when it was offered many years ago. Editor of the Newsletter at the time, I recall the author(s) placing a
messages.messageBody:
Yes, I should had bought a copy of that index when it was offered "many years ago." Editor of the Newsletter at the time, I recall the author(s) placing a one-time ad in the Newsletter offering their index for, I think, around fifty bucks. Never got around to buying a copy at the time; too tight to pay today's price for it now. Thanks for looking up the owl, Craig. Will check it out.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Craig Harris
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, July 19, 2003 2:16 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?


Once again, Tompkins' "People, Places and Things In Henri Joly's
Legend in Japanese Art" comes to the rescue with a reference on p.
122 and p. 544 in addition to the one you found on p. 43, Ron.

Unfortunately my copy of Legend is not here at the moment, so someone
else will have to look those up and report.

Craig Harris


On Sat, 19 Jul 2003 13:54:29 -0500, Ron Hartmann wrote:
>Hi -
>
>I found a brief explanation in Joly's "Legend in Japanese Art" on
>p.43 but could find nothing elsewhere in the book about owls. (You
>need the Japanese name for "owl" to find it, if it exists.)
>
>In the 2-volume set "Tsuba" and "Kodogu" by (I think) H.U.B. Velag--
>German publication from a few years ago--the Kodogu volume shows a
>kozuka (KO-51) with an owl being used as falcon bait, and a kogai
(K-
>11)showing an owl on a tree branch. Each item has a description of
>the design explaining the evilness of the owl (poor guy).
>
>This is all I could find here.
>
>Ron
>STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi - I found a brief explanation in Joly s Legend in Japanese Art on p.43 but could find nothing elsewhere in the book about owls. (You need the Japanese
messages.messageBody:
Hi -

I found a brief explanation in Joly's "Legend in Japanese Art" on p.43 but could find nothing elsewhere in the book about owls. (You need the Japanese name for "owl" to find it, if it exists.)

In the 2-volume set "Tsuba" and "Kodogu" by (I think) H.U.B. Velag--German publication from a few years ago--the Kodogu volume shows a kozuka (KO-51) with an owl being used as falcon bait, and a kogai (K-11)showing an owl on a tree branch. Each item has a description of the design explaining the evilness of the owl (poor guy).

This is all I could find here.

Ron
STL

From: David Zincavage
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, July 19, 2003 12:52 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?

Hi David -

After asking about this subject I did locate a couple references to the owl motif, both very dark and negative as you pointed out. One called the owl the "messenger of the devil!" Thinking about this, I wonder why the owl would had been used on kodogu, specifically menuki, unless of course it was to imply death from the sword, or something like that. (Seems the poor old owl is getting a bad rap! Neat bird!)

Ron
STL

It was these later, negative associations that crossed from China to Japan. messages.msgSnippet: Hi - Looking at some menuki depicting (I think) a male and female owl sitting in a pine tree (branch). Realized I never really understood the meaning of the
messages.messageBody:
Hi -

Looking at some menuki depicting (I think) a male and female owl sitting in a pine tree (branch). Realized I never really understood the meaning of the "owl" and thought somebody might jump in here and explain it for all to learn from.

Thanks!

Ron
STL
